Award.AwardTitle: Travel Support for The 44th Annual International Conference on Parallel Processing (ICPP-2015)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: This award provides travel support for graduate students to attend the 44th Annual Conference on Parallel Processing to be held in Beijing, China from September 1-4th, 2015. ICPP is a premier conference in parallel and distributed systems. A committee will be selected to choose the travel awardees according to the following criteria. The first priority will give to students who are from under-represented groups. The second priority will be given to those who normally could not attend the conference. Besides technical paper presentations, the venue offers a wide range of technical activities including panels, industry presentations, posters, demos, and keynote talks. Attending such high-caliber technical venues is extremely valuable for future researchers. This award will enable the supported attendees to be exposed to the state-of-the-art research in the field, to have the opportunity to interact with peer graduate students, researchers and experts from all over the world, to further gain knowledge that is likely to shape the future of the field.

Institution.Name: SUNY at Stony Brook
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK, THE

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project is to request National Science Foundation to provide $15K for travel support for graduate students to attend the 44th Conference on Parallel Processing held in Beijing, China from September 1st to 4th, 2015. The 44th ICPP conference is a premier conference in parallel and distributed systems. A committee for electing travel awardees was setup. The first priority was given to students who are from under-represented minority and female. The second priority was given to those who normally could not attend the conference. 13 graduate students from US based universities were selected to recieve the travel grants. The awardees attended the conference and most of them presented a paper at the conference. Besides technical paper presentations, the venue offered a wide range of technical activities including panels, industry presentations, posters, demos, and keynote talks. Attending such high-caliber technical venues was extremely valuable for future researchers. This award enabled the supported attendees to be exposed to the state-of-the-art research in the field, to have the opportunity to interact with peer graduate students, researchers and experts from all over the world, to further gain knowledge that is likely to shape the future of the field (e.g., in terms of technology, standards, etc). 

 


Last Modified: 05/04/2016
Modified by: Yuanyuan Yang
